comment._content: Chance Vought F8U-1 Crusader of VF-154 ‘Grand Slammers’ Modex 411 about to launch from CVA-19 USS Hancock. Picture dated November 25, 1957 VF-154 was the first front line Navy Crusader squadron to carrier qualify. Flight deck of USS Hancock under way, with control island and its open topped flying bridge, bridge below and Flag bridge below that. Plus above all that, the ships radars, radio masts and many onlookers. The above ‘flickr pic may also be viewed in a PDF document with download option here: (scroll down to page 126 using slider bar on right) es.scribd.com/doc/60152224/Vought-s-F-8-Crusader-Navy-Fig... “VF-154 F8U-1 143697 launching from USS Hancock (CVA-19) on 11-25-57. The steam catapult has just been fired (USN).” Based at NAS Moffet Field California, in early 1957 VF-154 became the first Pacific Fleet fighter squadron to receive the revolutionary new Crusader and assigned to USS Hancock. This relatively small "Essex Class" attack carrier had been drastically modified to enable operation of the new faster heavier jets - if not entirely adequately as there were several VF-154 F8U-1 carrier crashes that in 1958 caused the squadron to be sent ashore for an extended period in the Pacific during its first deployment aboard USS Hancock. Anecdotal commentary of VF-154 operations aboard USS Hancock during 1958 may be read here on an F8U-1 Crusader internet webpage: www.aero-web.org/specs/vought/f8u-1.htm I was aboard the USS Hancock CVA-19 Sept 1957 to April 1959 as at LTJG Gunnery Dept Ship's company. VF 154 was commanded by F.X.Timmes. LCD Baldwin was the XO. During qualification flights off the California coast prior to our deployment to WestPac several of the pilots had problems getting the F-8U Crusader on the deck of the Hancock. Major John Glenn, USMC fighter pilot, came aboard the Hancock for 10 days and help get the situation stabilized. Major Glenn was the typical hot-fighter jock. No one knew he would be an Astronaut, but you knew he was going places! I was on the o7 level of the Hancock when Lt. Ramsey was killed during flight ops. The right wheel assembly gave way during his landing and the plane skidded off the deck. He got back to approximately 600 feet and ejected but the chute didn't completely deploy. A sad day for the entire ship. 12/03/2008 @ 17:41 [ref: 23181] Dedicated website with pictures of VF-154s early period with the F8U-1 and interesting historical comment: www.miottelcollection.com/index/Callsign+%22Crash%22+Page+1 www.miottelcollection.com/uploads/F8Firstnational.jpg www.miottelcollection.com/uploads/f8cat.jpg www.miottelcollection.com/uploads/cat1.jpg (courtesy of John ‘Crash’ Miottel) Another image of the ‘flickr’ pic above may also be viewed here: www.miottelcollection.com/uploads/f8cat2.jpg
